repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe  - Social Sector
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social Sector Support
            Project for Sao Tome and Principe were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was modest, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: improved donor
            coordination in the health sector would have been desirable.
            However, there are no clear signs that this lack of
            coordination was costly since the targets were met and
            exceeded. Overall, the education sector performed better
            than the health sector in terms of implementation, even
            though both equally suffered institutional instability,
            including frequent changes of the Ministers, high attrition
            rate and limited capacity. The use of a fiduciary agency for
            project management was critical for successful
            implementation by country institutions. Project
            Administrative and Fiduciary Agency, or AFAP's role in
            project implementation went far beyond fiduciary management;
            it also acted as a technical assistant to the health and
            education ministries in various aspects of project
            execution, particularly by supporting the development of
            terms of reference, contributing to technical discussions,
            and training staff on monitoring and evaluation. In
            addition, in a context of frequent ministerial change and
            associated staffing instability, AFAP played a significant
            role in maintaining dialogue within government and with its
            external partners. By its experience and reputation, AFAP is
            well placed to become a government agency for project
            management. Having one project for the two social sectors in
            a small country promoted relative economies of scale for the
            fiduciary and procurement functions of the project, as well
            as for Bank supervision.

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Additional
            Financing for the Social Sector Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Additional Financing for the Social Sector Support Project
            is to improve the delivery of basic health services, with a
            focus on greater and equitable access, better quality and
            improved local governance of services. The Additional
            Financing (AF) in the amount of SDR1.4 (US$2.1 million
            equivalent) was approved by the Board on May 4, 2010 and
            became effective on November 11, 2010 with the closing date
            set for December 31, 2011. The AF was sought to provide
            additional resources to scale up the original project
            activities and to implement two additional activities. The
            extension of the closing date will allow the Ministry of
            Health (MoH) to complete the remaining activities, namely 1)
            the construction and rehabilitation of health centers; 2)
            purchase of vehicles and hospital equipment; and 3)
            technical assistance to complete the health information
            system and human resources strategy.

display_title.display_title:
Sao Tome and Principe -
            Additional Financing for the Social Sector Support Project :
            restructuring : Main report

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Social Sector
            Support Project : additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide an additional grant to
            the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe for the
            Social Sector Support Project (SSSP). The additional
            financing (AF) is sought to provide additional resources to
            scale up the original project activities and to implement
            two additional activities under component B, Delivery of
            Basic Health Services, and component C, Cross-Sector Issues
            (Malaria and HIV/AIDS). The additional financing will cover
            only the health and the cross-sector HIV/AIDS and malaria
            components of the SSSP, as the Government's education
            program has recently benefited from a US$3.6 million
            Catalytic Fund Grant. The original activities to be scaled
            up include: (i) rehabilitation of health facilities; and
            (ii) institutional support to the Ministry of Health (MoH).
            The additional activities include: (i) construction of
            residences for health staff in remote areas in order to
            improve the availability of health services; and (ii)
            capacity development of the health training school, and
            training of health personnel, including nurses, in order to
            increase the availability and quality of human resources in
            the sector. All activities to be financed under the
            additional financing are part of the Annual Work Plan (AWP)
            under the original project, which was agreed upon between
            the Government and the Bank in October 2009.

Sao Tome and Principe - Social Sector
